qas.question: What is a characteristic of iron sulfide?
What makes pure metals impure metals?
What are the three common impurities in aluminum alloys?
Using fluxes and chemical additives during the alloying process does what?
What is the term for desired elements in an alloy?
What is a rare impurity in steel?
Lithium, sodium and what other elements are common in steel?
Chemical what are used during alloying to add impurities?
What element from the air does not easily combined with most metals?

context: Although an alloy is technically an impure metal, when referring to alloys, the term "<b4_0>impurities<b4_0/>" usually denotes those elements which are not desired. These impurities are often found in the base metals or the solutes, but they may also be introduced during the alloying process. For instance, <b5_0>sulfur<b5_0/> is a common impurity in steel. Sulfur combines readily with iron to form iron sulfide, which is <a0_0>very brittle<a0_0/>, creating weak spots in the steel. <a2_0>Lithium, sodium and <b6_0>calcium<b6_0/><a2_0/> are common impurities in aluminium alloys, which can have adverse effects on the structural integrity of castings. Conversely, otherwise pure-metals that simply contain <a1_0>unwanted impurities<a1_0/> are often called "impure metals" and are not usually referred to as alloys. <b8_0>Oxygen<b8_0/>, present in the air, readily combines with most metals to form metal oxides; especially at higher temperatures encountered during alloying. Great care is often taken during the alloying process to <a3_0>remove excess impurities<a3_0/>, using fluxes, chemical <b7_0>additives<b7_0/>, or other methods of extractive metallurgy.
